unit_learning_outcomes.description: Apply key planning concepts to describe and explain contemporary planning issues.
Draw on a range of academic and policy sources to examine key planning theories.
Identify the role of key stakeholders, government and non-government actors in shaping planning systems.
Deliver planning information effectively through text, oral and visual communication forms.
Identify and describe planning systems and legal frameworks.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Readings and other preparation for classes

assessments.description: In class group presentation and individual written report (1500 words) based on a field trip and analysis of the planning issues, governance and stakeholders relevant to the area
Discussion and reflection on weekly topics in short written text
1,000 word essay that evaluates a theoretical framework that has influenced urban planning
1,500 word report analysing and comparing the NSW planning system with another planning system

data.description: This unit provides students with an understanding of what is meant by planning, what theories underpin the practice of planning, and the historical basis for planning. Building on this foundation the unit will focus on what systems govern planning by drawing on planning system examples from overseas, Australia and NSW. The unit explores the key legal frameworks of these systems and introduces students to the organisations and stakeholders involved in planning. The unit critically evaluates the purpose of planning and its role in the creation of cities and development in Australia.
